text: Is BSP considered to have negative expected value (-EV)?

text: Depends if you're backing or laying

elements.text: Depends if you're backing or laying

text: One point worth mentioning is that "unintended"  greening is possible when you can both back and lay at value prices. e.g. you have a model (which you are confident is correct) that tells you the "true" price is ~2.0. You initially get a back bet matched at 2.5 and then, a short time later, you have an opportunity to lay at 1.5. Both bets are _individually_ +EV (if your model's predicted price is correct), however you have also "greened" your position and reduced your exposure.

text: This raises a question...so we all generally agree that comparing our bet prices vs BSP is a good measure of model accuracy. Given that the BSP book is rarely 100%, presumably it makes sense to remove the overround/underround before comparing?

text: The "true" price can vary depending on what new information arrives during market evolution and the only real price is the one that has converged after the market is complete. For example, what do you think will happen if a horse bolts just before the race starts, or the trainer announces on TV that the horse isn't 100% fit, etc?

text: the topic of benchmarks is quite interesting though, especially from a modelling perspective

elements.text: the topic of benchmarks is quite interesting though, especially from a modelling perspective

text: So basically, you can only place bets based on the information available _at that time_, which may be +EV at time of placement but be -EV later on. The best we can do is approximate what we think is value and then assess a large sample of settled bets to confirm that we have an average EV > 0.

elements.text: So basically, you can only place bets based on the information available
at that time

, which may be +EV at time of placement but be -EV later on. The best we can do is approximate what we think is value and then assess a large sample of settled bets to confirm that we have an average EV > 0.

text: Ultimately, our accumulated P&L is the key metric, but that can take months to converge, so in the short term, BSP and/or vwap seems to be a sensible short term measure?

elements.text: Ultimately, our accumulated P&L is the key metric, but that can take months to converge, so in the short term, BSP and/or vwap seems to be a sensible short term measure?

text: Personally, Id say its a good measure as its widely available, easy to understand and as you say a short feedback time. If you have pricing data maybe the mid at off time maybe worth a look at (bit more of a hassle).
